markup_code: '''Euclid''' ({{IPAc-en|ˈ|juː|k|l|ɪ|d}}; {{lang-grc|[[Wikt:Εὐκλείδης|Εὐκλείδης]]}} – ''Eukleídēs'', {{IPA-grc|eu̯.klěː.dɛːs|pron}}; [[floruit|fl.]] 300 BC), sometimes given the name '''Euclid of Alexandria'''<ref name=":0">{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/41497065|title=Math and mathematicians : the history of math discoveries around the world|last=Bruno|first=Leonard C.|date=2003|origyear=1999|publisher=U X L|others=Baker, Lawrence W.|year=|isbn=0787638137|location=Detroit, Mich.|pages=125|oclc=41497065}}</ref> to distinguish him from [[Euclides of Megara]], was a [[Greek mathematics|Greek mathematician]], often referred to as the "founder of [[geometry]]"<ref name=":0" /> or the "father of geometry".
